author: SeeminglyScience
body:
PowerShell internally loads format data via the assorted `PSControl` classes.  While that API is public, I haven't been able to find a public way of importing them in an existing runspace.

I was able to export them first with `Export-FormatData`, but I'm hoping for a way to load them without writing to a file first.

Here's an example of what I'm looking for 

```csharp
// Existing public API
TableControl table = TableControl.Create()
    .AddHeader()
    .AddHeader()
    .StartRowDefinition()
        .AddPropertyColumn("Name")
        .AddPropertyColumn("Description")
    .EndRowDefinition()
.EndTable()

var etd = new ExtendedTypeDefinition(
    "MyModule.MyType",
    new[] { new FormatViewDefinition("Default", table) });

// Pseudo code, not a real API
Runspace.DefaultRunspace.UpdateFormatData(etd, shouldPrepend: false);
```

----------------

comments.author: powercode
comments.body: I don't think there is a way. I've wanted to do the same, but never found a way. We should fix it.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: Yeah, this really ought to have parity with Update-TypeData in PS as well. Update-FormatData doesn't accept anything other than file input either.

comments.author: Jawz84
comments.body:
I am willing to put some effort into this. 
I am thinking three parameter sets: 
- Path (-PrependPath -AppendPath)
- Dynamic (-TypeName -ListViewProperties -TableViewProperties -WideViewProperty)
- Type (-TypeName -FormatViewDefinition)

Goes without saying we keep the path parameter set default and unaltered.
An advanced user can use the Type param set to leverage the control builder pattern to create a FormatViewDefinition. I am not aware of any real benefit of exposing the wrapping ExtendedTypeDefinition here, please let me know if I am overlooking something in that respect.
The Dynamic param set would be to enable simple addition of (or changes to) a view for a type. Only allow supplying a list of properties to display for any given viewtype. We create a FormatViewDefinition from those internally. I am not sure how we can set the order of those yet (if listview comes before tableview in a FormatViewDefinition, that view is the default view). Maybe we add a parameter -DefaultView [Table|List|Wide]?

I have done a little POC with just the Type param set, but I am still a bit unsure which parts of the Path implementation need to stay and which parts can be left out. 
The db holding the views is buried like four layers deep, making it a bit complicated to unravel. 

I would like to hear feadback on the basic view I layed out above, and am also open to suggestions and any insights in the intricacies of the db.

title: Supported way to load ExtendedTypeDefinition
